p: In Italy, ethnobotanical surveys have received increasing attention in recent decades, seeking to investigate the traditional uses of plants and their products (e.g., [ 18, 19, 20]). Some of these studies focus on wild edible plants (e.g., [ 21, 22]), while others infer the use of wild plants as food through more general studies of ethnobotany (e.g., [ 23, 24]). In this regard, the literature in Italy lacks the coverage of some major issues focusing on plants used as spices.
